description: A waist-length overcoat with an integral chemical hood, an expandable pocket sewn into the left sleeve, and Velcro fastenings on the wrists and zipper, this jacket forms half of the US military’s CBRN JSLIST overgarment. Constructed with an inner layer of carbon discs that keep harmful chemicals from penetrating through the suit and a selectively permeable membrane that lets perspiration escape, the garment’s meant to be either worn over a regular uniform or alone for maximum breathability. Unsealed and exposed to the elements, it will likely last a day before its carbon layer is exhausted and the PPE loses its protective nature.
//: I wasn’t able to find numbers for actual issued overcoats, but I was able to find rough statistics for the MIRA Safety MOPP-1 CBRN suit, which is functionally the same: https://www.mirasafety.com/products/cbrn-protective-mopp-suit. Material thicknesses are my best guess, which is to say I didn’t find any numbers, plugged in some values that felt about right, slapped them on a plastic lunchbox, and committed them. If you have or find better values, feel free to update accordingly.
//2: The suit’s outer shell is a 50/50 blend of nylon and cotton rip-stop material, attached to an inner lining of activated carbon discs embedded within the fabric of a selectively permeable, breathable inner membrane: https://kohantextilejournal.com/cbrn-personal-protective-clothing/. Nylon material represents, spoilers, the nylon/ synthetic fabric element, canvas represents the rip-stop woven cotton used in the suits to make it tougher, charcoal represents the carbon beeds, and lycra seemed like the best candidate to model the inner membrane.
//3: The trader avoid flag is present as the suit is, without a hermetically sealed bag, functionally a one-time consumable on a countdown timer to becoming a worse jumpsuit. While some NPCs, indeed, most NPCs, would probably not know this information, there’s no way to selectively pick and choose who does and who doesn’t.

description: A waist-length overcoat with an integral chemical hood, an expandable pocket sewn into the left sleeve, and Velcro fastenings on the wrists and zipper, this ripped and torn jacket used to form half of the US military’s CBRN JSLIST overgarment.  Constructed with an inner layer of carbon discs to keep harmful chemicals from penetrating through the suit and a selectively permeable membrane meant to let perspiration escape, its intended role has been rendered void by the large amounts of lacerations that coat it, allowing any biohazard to infiltrate the coat unimpeded.  It's little more than a glorified jacket at this point, and not even a particularly good one at that; you’d be better off just discarding it.

description: An old, double-rubber-lined NBC trench coat from the Soviet Union with an elasticized chemical hood and sleaves, this mass-produced article of PPE prevents harmful chemicals from penetrating your body by cocooning you in a glorified envelope of rubber.  While the garment’s excellent at keeping you safe from NBC hazards, it also prevents either heat or perspiration from escaping, rendering you a sweaty mess in even mildly hot climates.  Popular before the Cataclysm for practical use among fisherman and mushroom gatherers and a collector's item in surplus circles, the suit must be paired with a gasmask, chemical overboots, and gloves for complete NBC protection.
//: This coat shouldn’t be added to military loot spawns, common civilian clothing, or regular sources of clothing loot. It should only appear in sensible collector settings or as last-ditch NBC protection somebody would have shoved in a bag during a bugout scenario.
//2: The coat’s constructed around an internal canvas layer coated by dual layers of rubber, as modelled in the material specifications. I wasn’t particularly in the mood to slice up my OZK to measure the exact thickness of each individual strata, so the material thicknesses are based on my best guess.

pocket_data.//: Move cost's stupidly high as it’s a teeny tiny rubberized pocket on the inside of the suit with an overhanging flap and an opening barely big enough for two fingers. It’s only really practical for spare lace storage.
